>>56724797

>25 March 2003: A friendly fire ("blue-on-blue") incident in Basra in which one Challenger 2 of the Black Watch Battlegroup (2nd Royal Tank Regiment) mistakenly engaged another Challenger 2 of the Queen's Royal Lancers after detecting what was believed to be an enemy flanking manoeuvre on thermal equipment. The attacking tank's second HESH round hit the open commander's hatch lid of the QRL tank sending hot fragments into the turret, killing two crew members. The hit caused a fire that eventually ignited the stowed ammunition, destroying the tank. This is only Challenger 2 to be destroyed on operations.
>August 2006: An RPG-29 capable of firing a tandem-charge penetrated the frontal lower underbelly armour of a Challenger 2 commanded by Captain Thomas Williams of The Queens's Royal Hussars south east of al-Amarah, southern Iraq. Its driver, Trooper Sean Chance, lost part of his foot in the blast; two more of the crew were slightly injured. Chance was able to reverse the vehicle 1.5mi (2.4km) to the regimental aid post despite his injuries. The incident was not made public until May 2007; in response to accusations that crews had been told the tank was impervious to the insurgents' weapons, the MoD said "We have never claimed that the Challenger 2 is impenetrable." Since then, the explosive reactive armour has been replaced with Chobham Armour and the steel underbelly lined with armour as part of the Streetfighter upgrade as a direct response to this incident.
>6 April 2007: in Basra, Iraq, a shaped charge from an IED penetrated the underside of a tank resulting in the driver losing a leg and causing minor injuries to another soldier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56721227
>Modern sabot rounds produce their own spin

They do not spin at all, they are fin stabilized, shot out of a smoothbore barrel. If the barrel is rifled, you use a slipping sabot, so the arrow spins slowly. This actually increases accuracy since it evens out aerodynamic asymmetries and also helps with sabot separation since the sabot is spinning very fast. The downside is that you lose a few tens of meters per second in muzzle velocity.

>>56728536
>Freezing to death actually seems like a pretty peaceful way to go once you've gotten past the point of no return, you just feel very warm and sleepy and slowly fade away.
I did not feel that but I had been wounded in the arms. I felt very cold, pain in my arms and legs that feeling of ice coming in my bones and down my spine. Everything became very bright and I saw or dremed or had a vision was on a hill on a barren place with scrubby pine trees and there was a huge black horse circling me slowly and I could hear dogs howling linked a kennel, it was cold there too and I could see the breath from the horses nose and the rider had heavy black leather boots and the stirrups were shaped like rectangular bells. I knew it was death, he had come for me but I could not move. Then I woke up to two of my pals, one pumping my chest to start my heart and the other rubbing my face and slapping it. My heart stopped and I was stretched out when they found me, they thought I was dead. They both were killed a week or so later one shot himself when he was wounded and the other died in an assault on trenchwork. I deserted because the wounds on my hands were so bad I was no longer useful anyway and the hospital and evacuation had collapsed. I knew there was a breakout charge planned at dawn so I just walked in the opposite direction and then hid under a trailer. I have never been right in the head since really.

Sherlock Holmes carried one, and so did a couple of the bad guys in the stories, it was a Brit thing. Thugs would try to rob people, so they defended themselves with essentially metal clubs disguised as wooden walking-sticks; in context of the time and society, it's like a really classy EDC weapon; makes Holmes out to be a gentleman who isn't afraid to get his hands dirty beating up badguyz, and yet is more genteel than the more practical Watson who more often relies on his Army revolver. Especially since Holmes carried not a mere walking-stick, but a loaded hunting-crop, marking him even more as an upper-middle-class gentleman. The prototypical James Bond- or Kingsman-like figure!

Holmes also references a thick walking stick known as a "Penang lawyer", probably named after the island in Malaysia named after the hardwood tropical tree. Meaning something similar to "Kentucky windage", ie a joke about how legal affairs are settled out in the backwaters of the Empire.

posts.name: Battle Priest

>>56716438
>How would I go about figuring out what should go into the jacket without being too redundant?
Look at what you have and what it covers.
Consider variables such as weather, food, water, ammunition, nighttime, etc.
If you consider those to be dangerous holes in your system, then plug them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56716438
As line 1, do you mean using it without the chest rig at all, or just storing supplementary items in case you take off the chest rig?

I suggest wearing both and seeing what you actually use out of the chest rig. When you take something out, put it back in the jacket instead. Sooner or later you'll more or less know what you need to put in the jacket. Add in the items that you're unlikely to use but really want just in case (ammo, compact emergency blanket, etc) and you should be good. I've used a gortex parka as my main before, you don't really need a chest rig if you aren't carrying much ammo.

I would totally jump on a cheap used one. I'll probably buy the JXP10, too, but not for practical reasons.

As far as I'm aware, cylinder is the way to go for chokes when shooting slugs. Your Mossberg probably has a cylinder choke already. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56720586
IFAK: get an ACU one if you can find one for really cheap. I looked on Venture Surplus and they're up to like $12 now without the insert and they have coyote brown ones for a little more. Get a tourniquet from North American Rescue ($25-30), you might be able to source some of the other stuff for cheaper. Don't carry or use needle chest decompression needles or oropharyngeal airways without training. Not that people use OPAs often anyway.

For storing water, just buy a nalgene or knock off. Or 1 quart canteens and pouches if you want, should be pretty cheap.

For the 3 day pack I'd probably just buy one from walmart or buy this:
https://www.venturesurplus.com/products/us-army-3-day-assault-pack-no-stiffener/
The stiffener is just a plastic plate, you could make one and sew up any little holes. $15 is a steal.

For a flashlight, I like the Litezall rechargable chinesium walmart one, it's bright and has good throw. It's like $15. You'd be better off buying a Streamlight Polytac or Protac, though, it's worth it and they're like $45-70, you can mount them to a gun. Probably get a little $1 flashlight or worklight for small tasks, too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56721196
>IFAK
Ziplock bag (doubles as additiomal chest seal also), stick it in whatever GP pouch you can get for cheapest. Then, in order of importance:
>2x genuine tourniquet (sof-t, cat7 if american, sich or dnipro if european - cat7s cost double in europe)
>15-20 yards of regular gauze, rolled or z folded (normal pharmacy gauze rolls are fine)
>2x acewrap or whatever bandage
>medical tape / duct tape, at least a few yards
>chest seal: HALO, Hyfin or learn how to make one from a plastic baggie. the result will be the same
>trauma shears ($10 ones are fine, no need for the expensive ones)
>nitrile gloves
>burn dressing (not really an IFAK must have but is nice to have and takes up no space)

>>56710782
>right now learning to become a welder.

Good, but expect if you want money to hit the road unless you have local fab shops etc.

Pipelining, shutdown work etc is where the money is but our students often did decently wire welding trailers and working for an ATM/gun safe company locally. Read your ass off and get in as much time under the hood as you possibly can. I volunteered to help my welding and later machine shop class which worked superbly, especially because instructors are asked for references. Team players are highly valued.

Is your class a workforce training deal or a two-year degree? The latter is useful towards knowing CWI stuff (more money). Study professional fora like the AWS forums etc and ask pros who do what interests you about the best plan of attack. Learn to fit, too because if you don't pass a hiring test as a welder you can fit and learn welding on the job.

The Northern Alliance was a bunch of different warlords, many of them enemies and rivals. The NATO-backed Kabul regime was the same thing. The relatives of politicians and the warlords were running most of the opium trade. The Afghan Taliban taxed existing poppy farmers in areas they controlled or contested, but they never grew or traded in it themselves.

Giving any power to the warlords and their allies, without NATO holding it together, would have just resulted in a civil war between them. That doesn't hurt AQ either, they would have thrived on it. The reason the Afghan Taliban formed in the first place was because of the ensuing civil war in the first half of the 1990s after the Soviets left. The IEA ended the civil war by taking most of the cities and the south/east.

There's violence now (from ISK and NRF) but its far less than during the US occupation, or during the first half of the 1990s. Any AQ activity in Afghanistan has been irrelevant since the mid 2010s. Since they couldn't implement Salafism, they and ISIS have focused on West Asia and Africa instead since the late 2000s and early 2010s.

The IEA also crushed most of ISK in the late 2010s whereas the former Kabul regime let them run wild, partly to blame their attacks on the Taliban and partly to keep the US staying longer in Afghanistan. The YPG/SDF is basically pulling the same shit in Northeast Syria but ISIS is not a viable threat in the north because you have rival Jihadists and SNA strongholds, Turkey, and even Iran, Russia and Assad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56721876
>10-shot group was just under 2.5 MOA at 150 and it stands
That's not hot it works. If you have 2moa at 100yards, then it's not your same MOA at 150yards. MOA is measured as your average spread across 5groups at 100yards. If you're shooting at 150yards, that's no longer your MOA, that's just your spread. MOA is a formula measured at 100yards. That's how you can say 5moa to the right or aim 3moa vertically. Scopes come in MOA or Mils, you can't just shoot at the range you want and call it MOA.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56726199
>but objectively managing a 2.5 MOA group isn't exactly the same at 100, 150 or 300
This isn't dificult. A 2.5 MOA group at 100 yards is 2.5 inches across. A 2.5 MOA group at 200 yards is 5 inches across. A 2.5 MOA group at 300 yards is 7.5 inches across.
What is difficult is doing the backwards math on the fly from a 3.75in group at 150 yards to figure out a 2.5 MOA, which is why people thought you were confusing inches and MOA and not actually doing the math. 99% of people use a range ending in 00 to establish MOA because of the incredibly simple math involved.
It would be like if I casually said I get 1.5 MOA at 70 yards with my M14. Are you going to assume I'm actually right and have done the math and believe it at face value, or believe that I don't know what MOA means?

>>56722052

Nerfanon here, getting a lot of use time on my own Nightfox Cape lately as well, super fun times. Unfortunately, the Cape's framerate is actually considered top tier for budget 940nm digitals; Nightfox uses an unusually high/fast shutter rate to get their FPS even that high, which reduces effective range to about 150 feet maximum and a mere 100-120 feet under average conditions. It's a great short-range starter/trainer/loaner digital at a very low price, and with native head-mounting capabilities usually not seen until you hit the $300+ range, but at the end of the day it's still a budget digital with all that entails. I still love mine of course.

That said, I've got a chance to score a brand-new SiOnyx Aurora Black with the SiOnyx 5W 940nm IR illuminator and all the trimmings (Marsupial carry pouch, batteries, SD card, Pelican case, etc) for like $500. My use case is mixed-light settings where i2 might suffer extensive wear, but no issues with me just blasting active IR everywhere. Is this kit a good buy under those circumstances? The Black usually runs $700 and the IR illuminator $150 by themselves.

>If their homeland sucks, like Canada, they should make it better instead of swarming better countries

Many times, this takes nearly an entire lifetime or longer. The majority of people in any country at any given time are not going to just live a shit life so the next generations can have it better. America became the behemoth it is due to industrial might because the things people gained from having massive industry were things they wanted. You're also faced with the fact that culturally (for lack of a better term) such tasks are just a no-go in some places; no matter how much of a hard-working well-meaning guy you are, if you're from Afghanistan for example it will always be a terrible place to live in nearly every metric because one man or a small handful cannot change an entire nation on their own, especially with everyone else's priorities and wants being actively detrimental. And that's something that would take several lifetimes, if that, to change. Most people are fond of their homeland, but aren't willing to live a life of toil for the hope that maybe the next citizen has it better.

So they'll hop the fence, board that raft, marry that fat pig for a Green Card, whatever they need as long as the pros outweigh the risk and they're capable enough. I know some say "no immigration of any sort forever", but that would not only be impossible politically, it would cripple the country in several ways. People come over on business all the time, they come over for tourism, they legally work seasonally doing shit jobs Americans won't for basically no money; you could avoid them abusing this and immigrating illegally by making such things verboten, but you would annihilate the tourism industry overnight, oranges would be $5 each or something equally ridiculous (that or the collapse of a lot of rural America), and international trade would take a massive nosedive. All you can really do is filter out the least-driven an least-able, but some always will.

1. Punch out disk
2. Center disk on hole with desired od
3. Use bushing to center undersized punch
4. Press through
5. Repeat as necessary
lube and annealing where necessary ofc.
The lower die will need some of its holes radiused and the drawing punches will need blunting. With a light duty die like this it's probably best to stick to balloon head/rimfire cases.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56710276
Ignoring the Germans because they were the second worst navy of the war, only beating out the soviets
The Japanese entire strategy was based on the idea of the kantai kessen, the decisive naval battle against America (and specifically America, they hyper focused on America to the point of not really being a good general purpose navy to fight anyone else)
The idea would be that per USN doctrine, the American battleships would set sail and sail across the pacific. Along the way Japanese carrier and submarine forces would harry them to attrit the larger American fleet. Once they reached the designated spot (said spot changed over the years), the Japanese light forces including the kongos, which were doctrinally not capital ships, would commit to a mass night attack and the following morning the Japanese battleships would clean up
All of their design and training decisions were in pursuit of this battle. This is why they had good torpedoes, but also why they made their cruisers deathtraps by giving them said torpedoes. This is why their light forces were so proficient at night battles until the Americans caught the hang of it, this is why they had such large modern submarines and then didn't use them for convoy raiding, this is why their light forces were so completely fucking bad at asw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56719811
>but the battleship in the Naval World was still the king
????
That was dispelled rapidly and while there were some battleship admirals who popped up now and then, they mostly were beaten into line. Even career battleship officers like Fletcher, Halsey, and Brown quickly accepted the aircraft carrier as the principle weapon of naval warfare. The Gilbert Islands raids, attacks on the Japanese landing forces in New Guinea, and other early actions showed lessons that the US leadership did not ignore. Coral Sea removed the last of the holdouts and by the time of Guadalcanal, naval commanders were making decisions around the needs and protection of the carriers, even at the expense of abandoning landing ships.

> traditional naval doctrine around Mahan (ftfy)
They followed Mahan's principles in regards to as maintaining lines of communication and establishing strong points, but they absolutely did not follow the core tenant of his that you should seek the enemy fleet and destroy it in pitched battle. The Japanese went all in on Mahan and their dogma of Kantai Kessen did not do them any favors.

If anything, the US strategy in the Pacific has more in common overall (emphasis on overall) with Corbett's ideas. The campaigns, such as the Solomons, always sought to isolate the offensive theater and achieve overwhelming local superiority while preventing enemy replenishment. Using submarines in commerce raiding instead of fleet pickets was more in line with Corbett's principle of directly attacking enemy lines of communication. The Americans also sought to decline battle until they could use strategic maneuver to achieve tactically advantageous battles.

>>56719811
>Carriers were of major interest, but the battleship in the Naval World was still the king
Nah
by December 1941 the world knew carriers were the decisive capital ships of the battle fleet; even the RN knew it, though they risked one, just ONE action without carrier cover (because HMS Indomitable couldn't repair and reach in time) and paid the price for it.

However, battleships and heavy cruisers were still an essential part of the fleet, though defensively, even into the mid-50s, because carriers couldn't fight at night or in mist.

>>56721067
>they absolutely did not follow the core tenant of his that you should seek the enemy fleet and destroy it in pitched battle
They did - King's and Nimitz's priorities were always "sink the carriers" first, support the Army second - but they didn't neglect the island campaign or sub/convoy interdiction, the latter probably influenced by WW1 experience, whereas the IJN mainly neglected these other areas and did a lot of lolwut adhoc improvisation, possibly due to lack of resources... no shit given they were killing themselves just building something that juuuust might conceivably take out the US Navy's extant combat divisions

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56723071
>King's and Nimitz's priorities were always "sink the carriers" first
No, it wasn't. If that was their priority, then they would have actually sought out and directly challenged the Combined Fleet. They never did that unless they had prepared an ambush like Midway or had a decisive tactical overmatch like the Philippine Sea and Leyte Gulf.

The key priorities in the early stages of the Pacific War for the American admirals were to secure the areas north of Austrailia, maintain supply lines to forward staging areas, and preserve the fleet as a fighting force while strength is built in the homeland.

Obviously when the enemy was encountered, they wanted to win and tried to destroy the enemy, but they never went out looking for those fights in the early war. The American admirals would have done that if they were following Mahan's philosophy of sea control like that anon claimed they were.

>>56724455
>If that was their priority, then they would have actually sought out and directly challenged the Combined Fleet
Even Mahan himself didn't advocate for that, in his battle plan to fight the RN. Operationally, he advocated a combined amphibious-high seas strategy of attacking overseas territories (in his given example, Canada) and harrassing supply lines, taking the fleet engagement only when favourable. Geostrategically, he had a much more balanced view that included trade protection, an aspect the Japanese totally ignored. The Japanese version of Mahanian doctrine was autistically extreme; the USN strategy was more akin to original Mahanian theory.

>The Short Victorious War is a science fiction novel by American writer David Weber, first published in 1994. It is the third book in the Honor Harrington series.

>Its title comes from a quotation by Vyacheslav von Plehve in reference to the Russo-Japanese War: "What this country needs is a short, victorious war to stem the tide of revolution." "The families who rule the People's Republic of Haven are in trouble. The treasury's empty, the Proles are restless, and civil war is imminent.

>The Salyut 3, although called a "civilian" station, was equipped with a "self-defence" gun which had been designed for use aboard the station, and whose design is attributed to Alexander Nudelman. These claims have reportedly been verified by Pavel Popovich, who had visited the station in orbit, as commander of Soyuz Due to potential shaking of the station, in-orbit tests of the weapon with cosmonauts in the station were ruled out. The gun was fixed to the station in such a way that the only way to aim would have been to change the orientation of the entire station. Following the last manned mission to the station, the gun was commanded by the ground to be fired; some sources say it was fired to depletion, while other sources say three test firings took place during the Salyut 3 mission.

posts.name: A2Grip
posts.com:
/arg/ Tasks of the month for Jan-2023
Maintenance-
Optics are useful on your rifle but they only work when you respect them, part of this is cleaning them.
>Do you have a lens blower?
>Do you have a lens brush?
>Do you have lens paper?
>Do you have lens cleaner?
How do you intend to carry this into the field with you?
You should at this point know how your optics degrade in relation to how dirty they get. Next time your optic is filthy take the opportunity to observe assorted distances at various times throughout the day to see how much clarity you lose.

Skill Sustainment-
Target: 9x9” Plate or similar paper
Rounds: 2-4 rounds
Equipment: SPR
After confirming zero at 100yd walk back to 200yd.
Action: Upon buzzer start standing @ low ready (real low ready, not wgws low ready), Drop to a knee and deliver two solid hits on the 9x9 plate and call your time. Add 1 second for each dropped shot
Total times (time+dropped penalty):
>Cold 9 sec = Par
>Warmed up 8 sec = par
>6 and below = cooking it
Record your times and experiment with the mag level on your SPR.

Improvement-
If you are using a harris or similar force to overcome style bipod you can improve deployment speed with a quick mod at home.
Get a 12” long piece of paracord and tie an overhand knot over itself 3 times in the center, some people like to leave a tail on longer guns. Grab one end of the line and tie it to a harris bipod leg above the release button with a suitable knot, repeat on the other leg. To deploy; pinch the knot or grasp the line that dangles between the legs when folded and yank down with a jerk motion. It will deploy both legs at once and doesn’t require you to reach across the bipod or juggle the gun when prone. More documentation: https://ridgelineshooting.com/bipod-paracord-hack/ and https://youtu.be/21Azmj0rJQ0

Post task of month times/feedback in thread

The Eastern Front is wildly overrated. Wildly overrated. Vatniks act like every single division was a mechanised one. The reality was 99% of formations on the Eastern front were trash leg infantry staring at each other from their trenches. Literal trash mobs. All of the attacking and real fighting was done by the same dozen or so formations on both sides. It's why you see the same unit names over and over again.
Meanwhile on the Western front in Normandy you had literally the cream of the german army, about a dozen elite mechanised/armoured formations facing off against the allies in an AO about the size of a shoebox.
Normandy was so far in advance of anything Russia was capable of it's genuinely worthless to try and make a comparison. Russia could NEVER have pushed off the beaches. Not ever.
It's kinda why blitzkrieg and deep battle are such memes. It's not some amazing tactic. It's literally putting your good troops where the enemy's aren't. It only happens when there's force overmatch. So Leg infantry vs leg infantry = meatgrinder. Mechanised manoeuvre formations vs mechanised manoeuvre formations = meatgrinder. Mechanised manoeuvre formations vs leg infantry = blitzkrieg.
Don't ever listen to wehraboos or vatniks about the Eastern front. There's more myths attached to there than any other place in the war. Not even the Battle of Britain compares for levels of bullshit.

>>56727768
Blows out barrels sooner. They should've went with the True Velocity polymer cased, it operated at a lower PSI to save the barrel more and recoil less. It needed more barrel to burn enough powder to meet the specs, but the gun was a bullpup so it could handle it. The gun also needed a much shorter suppressor since it had a longer barrel and lower velocity PSI.

Sig fucked up attempting to meet such high demands with such a short barrel. They cut the barrel to 13", upped the PSI to fucking hellish levels, and ended up having to use a longer suppressor as a result. They tried to reach a balance but didn't reach it at all, almost like they released an incomplete design. The result is the gun shooting at way too high a velocity for a reasonable barrel life, unbelievable recoil, and impossible for a human to safely shoot it without a suppressor or ear/eye pro (yes the muzzle flash is going to be insane, there's a reason they won't allow any reviewer to shoot it without the suppressor).

They honestly should've bullpupped it to allow for a longer barrel and less velocity demand. But that gun already existed. The milcorp picked Sig because they play ball with kickback schemes to embezzle money alloted for weapons purchases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56729974
Dude you could just divide the mass by the area to get SD.

6.8 (.277) is basically the same thing as 7mm (.284). SDs will be pretty much the same. If 7mm has adequate SD, so will 6.8. You can only go so many calibers long in bullet length, so 300 will always win, but still. 6.8 can theoretically have better SDs than 6.5, and that’s a very popular long range caliber.

To answer OPs question, an increase in pressure is effectively a proportional increase in energy density. It isn’t the 6.8x51 that’s better than other meme calibers, it’s the case tech. More energy density is always better. Higher velocities from smaller and lighter cases with higher magazine capacity. 6.8x51 is cool as a 308/6.5CM replacement, but I’d want to see other cartridges loaded to gigapressures in hybrid cases. 5.56, 5.7, 6.8SPC, the blackouts, etc. (their analogs really, I know we’ll never get actual 5.56 loaded to 80kpsi.)

>>56705752
1. The cummerbund was designed exclusively for fats. (I guess they know their market?)
2. The shoulder pads/buckles were poorly designed and interfere with shouldering and firing.
3. Unreasonably heavy. Almost a pound heavier than the comparably-specced First Spear Strandhogg. (2.5 vs. 1.7 pounds.) Nearly as heavy as the old-school LBT 6094, which is much more ruggedly built.
4. That stupid zipper is exposed and is gonna break. If you're going to have zippers on a fucking plate carrier, you at least need to cover it with a flap of nylon.
5. Too much padding.
> B-but it's comfy
Yeah, if you wear your carrier for five minutes. If you wear it for hours at a time, the padding adds substantial bulk and heat retention, and makes the carrier more difficult to clean and maintain.
6. Proprietary plastic for patent evasion.
Basically, it was designed by tards. The Strandhogg is probably "the best" civilian-accessible modern plate carrier.

Option two: Restrict access to civilians. "Oy! You don't need to own this military-grade plate carrier. It's only for... teh elite!"
Most of these companies go with option two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I took psilocybin mushrooms over a week ago, and it was heavily military themed. I took it with the intent to see if I really wanted to go back to active duty.

I just made a whole webpage dedicated to detailing my first (and probably last) shroom trip: https://asuras-nightmare.neocities.org/

Beware, it's 7600 words long if you really want to read it.

My trip didn't fit the narrative of what happens during a trip, like making me more "loving" and "open minded", finding some big truth out there I never would have figured out by myself, nor seeing colorful fun imagery and realizing "we are all one" or anything that would make me hug a tree. It sucked and just told me what I already know, but emotionally amplified by like 1000x.

I detailed what the trip was like and hopefully it's at least interesting, for people interested in joining, already serving, or other vets. It might encourage others to keep detailed record of their trips, shared or not.

I am aware that this journal might make me look like a total jackass, but whatever. It's real and I am not censoring it. Go ahead and laugh at me, I don't care. Especially the gym part.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56719058
What's even more crazy is that, scaled for population, it's not even all that bad. In general, wars have become much less deadly as technology and civilization has advanced.

That's 12,000 casualties a day, less then half those being immediate deaths (for at least the Soviets, Axis is harder to determine because prisoners were killed). There are 10 hour battles with 3 to maybe 10 times that many killed in a day, drawing from populations a tiny fraction of that size. Pic related, not one of the very highest, but most of a 40,000 man army butchered over several hours.

If you fought on the Eastern Front as a Russian, you still had better odds at surviving the war than not, by a solid margin. Same for all Germans who fought there. You have some wars, e.g., the First Crusade, where 65-80% of one force was dead by the end of the war.

The Thirty Years War killed 2.5 times more Germans than both World Wars combined. The Hugonaut Wars killed 4-8 times as many French as their atrocious losses in WWI.

By 2100, hopefully major wars so be a few thousand dead, with drone losses being how we measure scale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56719499
To be fair, worse casualty rates aren't all from battles being more deadly in the past. Armies had to march on foot for hundreds of miles through inclement weather with no water treatment or medicine while living off forage. You'd take 20% losses just traveling.

You'd also manage to depopulate areas so drastically because everyone was a near subsistence farmer and a harvest disruption could cause 1:20 people to drop dead or more.

Still is wild that conflicts could drop a regions population by like 50-60+% in extreme cases.

To nitpick: Old wars tended to spread their casualties out among all groups, since the big killers were generally starvation and disease that followed in the wake of the armies. posts.com:
This is something few people ever consider.
If you're a guerilla and a squadmate dies in a firefight, if you aren't prepared for it your whole team is in danger just from the corpse.
If a mass casualty event happens in an area you control, you have a biohazard to deal with.
If you capture a more "progressive" territory and say you want to remove onions, you'll need to know how to emphasize the removal part.

Handling corpses is an essential skill if you seriously believe SHTF stuff, because in such a scenario you won't have the time or resources to just make a big pit like a conventional military.

>>56586661
Alright, so I think I should post some updates. Little buddy isn't doing well. For a brief day or two, the increased meds seemed to be working, his liver swelling has gone down more and his eyes were clear and he could see me. Now he's not playing, not eating, not drinking. He lays under the dining room table, his eyesight seems to be bad again. All we could get him to eat was some tuna-flavored tapioca paste that the vet would give him (it's only like 6 calories per tube, so not much), and he drank a small amount of water, but that was on the morning of the 2nd. He's just returned to laying under the table and taking nothing, he feels cold to the touch.
By all accounts, it seems like his liver is failing, and he's probably going to die. We're now looking at an in-home euthanasia service so he doesn't need to leave his home or his family. If the weather in the morning permits, I'm going to bring him outside to the back yard. It's only fair, he's wanted to go out there for the whole of his short little life, and we kept saying he could when he was a little bigger in the spring, lest an owl or hawk grab him. I think now is the time to grant that wish, he won't last that long unless a miracle happens. I don't think he would run if he wanted to anyway.
Thanks for the sympathy and support that you guys have given through this ordeal. I may try to post some videos I have of him later if it's alright. I'm currently posting from work, so when I finally post again it will probably be after he's gone. I'm going to spend what time I have left with the little guy, keeping him company and taking some final vids and pics so I can remember him.

>>56612939
No kids myself, closest thing is my sister and she's getting a bit old. I know that a beloved pet dying does ruin the holiday season, just last year my cat of 10 years died shortly before NYE.
I'll try all I can anyways, I certainly don't want the little fella to die. I feel like I failed him. It just doesn't look good, since he's rejecting his meds and his liver numbers on his most recent visit were pretty bad. Our vet said that she had never seen a cat return from those numbers, but encouraged us to keep trying and that miracles happen every day.
I'm off work in the morning so I'll go with him to the vet myself if I can get us there and ask about any and all unexplored options. I have half a mind to ask if a liver transplant could save him, but I'm not sure if risking him dying on some operating table surrounded by unfamiliar people is worth it when he could die peacefully at home.
I also just can't guarantee I can get him there either, it's a long way and its a now a big risk to move him there.

>>56614972
Alright, last update. I took him outside a little before the vet came. He seemed a little confused. Sat with him a little before he decided he wanted to go back inside.
She came and confirmed that it was terminal, it was affecting his eyes and brain, and he was blind. His eyes were open, he just couldn't see anything, wasn't even blinking anymore.
We set him down on his favorite bed, the one he took over from the dogs. Put the bed in front of the Christmas tree, we didn't really have the time or thought to bother taking it down yet. She gave him the shot to put him under, startled him at first but then he began to calm down and go to sleep. We spoke to him and rang his bell as he drifted off (he used to ring a bell to get treats, even when he stopped eating he'd still ring it and purr). She made a few casts of his paw in clay as this happened.
She gave him the last shot after a little after that as we gathered around and patted him softly. He was gone in minutes.
We've all been crying, even before she got here we cried and sat around him. Even my normally stoic dad was bawling his eyes out so hard he was coughing, and this man didn't cry at his own mother's funeral.
I don't know what to do anymore, I feel empty inside. He won't be waiting for me at the bottom stair when I leave for work next weekend. He won't rush to the door to greet me when I come home, I'll never set his bell down for him to ring before he gets his favorite treats again, I'll never hear his sweet little voice call out to me again. I'd rather have died in his stead, he was only a baby. He was born in late summer, and he never lived to see the spring. I feel like I failed him.
I'm sorry there's not a happy end to this story guys. I'd have given anything to give him a few more years of life, I'd melt every gun I own in a huge fire and dump all my ammo in the sea if it meant he would have lived even a few more years. I can always buy more guns, I can't replace him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56615530
>I feel like I failed him.
You didn't. The day will come when you can accept that.

Something to consider, going into the future, not for anytime "too soon." I've buried about a dozen friends now, and these things helped out. Eventually.

You can honor the memory of your friend by adopting another who needs a home. There are millions, and you can give at least one a chance that they didn't have. It hurts, but they are also a comfort.

Something I learned was that a single cat gets a bit neglected, even in a house with best intentions. Humans just get wrapped up in things and distracted by Important Life Stuff. So, if you have the option, get more than one cat. Two works if that's already stretching your resources & space and you can still do it, but three seems to be an optimum. They have each other to explore & play and socialize with, humans present or not. They really are highly social, especially if their humans interact with them and show them how.

Two often work together, but the relationship can become one-sided. I've found that three create an unstable dynamic so that one doesn't dominate another & bully. No matter any conflict two get into, the third provides a distraction that breaks a pattern of regular abuse of one against another. You need to guide them, and be attentive should one personality just not work out for Reasons.

Anyway, the younger the better. They grow up as if they are brothers & sisters. How you teach them young will imprint for their entire lives, so put extra effort in early.

Cheers and good on ya' for having a huge heart. Peace to you and all of yours.

>>56647505
>cat just turned 1 a month or so ago, is that still young enough to get along with other cats
Yes, entirely. You'll need to do some research on introducing a new cat into a house that already has cats. There's do's & dont's to make it comfortable & happy for everyone.

First tip: new cat(s) should be younger than the older cat. There is automatic seniority dominance, which can be groomed into a relationship even if the dynamics change later. Any cat under ~3 years old is still largely a kitten & can be easily subverted with food, play, food, attention, play, food, more attention ... They tend to accept the newcomer as a playmate if the humans set the environment.

The established resident has run of the house, for example. Bring the newcomer in & they get locked in a room the first 24 hours before they meet so they get used to each other in the same house & their scents. For the first few months, until they clearly get along without harm to each other, the established senior gets the house, the newcomer gets put into a room if things get a bit spicy between them.

Get them eating together, do not allow them to eat each others' food, at least the first 6 months. Keep them close to each other, feed them at the same time, talk to both, give both attention, separate them (gently, no drama) if either infringes on the other.

Get them to play together. In the same room at first. Play with the senior cat first, draw the other in. I would walk around the room dragging 2 strings. Each would take their own string at first, after a few sessions they figured out playtime and even started wrestling each other without fighting.

Your cat is very young. This is the best time to introduce a new cat the same age or slightly younger. By the time they are 2 they will be like littermates for life. There are exceptions, but do your part and it's very rare. I brought a 6 month kitten into a house with a 7 year old cat. It worked out fine, but I put a lot into it up front.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56647505 >>56647880 --> CT'd -->
One thing you can take advantage of is that your cat is already a girl. She will be highly territorial. Bringing in another girl is not the optimal situation here, so try to bring in a younger male, maybe 6-8 or ~10 months. She will establish dominance, but will have mothering instinct triggered (very strong in cats) & set her littermate senses set tingling ... plus the spice of a sexy young male. This is probably your best option for best chances to succeed, especially if this is the first time you are attempting it.

Your current cat will have feelings on the issue. Be sensitive to them, talk to her about them, give her reassurance that she's still the prettiest girl, give extra grooming, playtime, attention in general. It'll smooth things out greatly for the first few weeks & months. The newcomer interrupts, give him attention, but don't stop giving the most attention to your good girl.

You are playing the role of the third cat I mentioned. Break up bad behavior patterns with firm authority, encourage good behavior patterns. My 7 year old always slept with me (a boy). The new kitten (also a boy) insisted on sleeping with us. The older cat objected & pouted, would walk away, but always come back because it was HIS bed. I fell asleep every night with one of them on each side of me, petting both of them until I fell asleep. They would both calm down & purr, so they could hear & smell each other but not see or touch. A month later they were falling asleep leaning against each other, in bed with me or otherwise.

The younger cat had huge kitten energy & bullied the older cat. I would distract him with playtime & put him in a (dark) room to give the older cat relief. Not a situation as likely for you, but could help in some cases.

Food discipline is important. They get the exact same thing at the exact same time. Nobody gets treats unless everybody gets treats. You can relax that later as appropriate.

You're building a pride.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56712861
The simplest process would probably just involve purifying sulfuric acid from an acidic volcanic spring, many of which have naturally high concentrations of sulfuric acid. The second simplest would involve burning any number of sulfur-containing minerals and bubbling the gas through water, which is the procedure used historically to produce it when the chemical industry consisted entirely of burning rocks, plants, and animals in a retort. Most production processes can also use platinum as a catalyst. Vanadium oxide is preferred because Platinum can be gradually leached when producing concentrated H2SO4 at scale. Platinum can be easily obtained in the quantities necessary for catalysis, if only from scavenging the catalytic converters from rusted out automobiles.

I'd recommend at least digging through 2-3 wikipedia articles before you pretend to be a chemist.

Saltpetre (one of the components of blackpowder) makes you feel horribly sick for a few days, but makes you *look* sick for even longer. It's a minor plot point in Day of the Jackal. But back in the day, it was one of the methods available for malingerers. Also, consuming saltpetre stops you from having erections which is why British boarding schools sometimes slipped it into the students' food. Otherwise, with a captive population of hundreds of teenaged boys and no women, there was a risk of things turning a little... prison-y.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56708743
Some types of smokeless powder (such as cordite) actually consist of long, extruded sticks. The first smokeless propellant (picrel), was called Poudre B (B for blanc, i.e. white, to contrast it with blackpowder) was made by passing the material through a pair of rollers until it was a thin, flat sheet which was then cut up like confetti. There's also some types of smokeless powder that are shaped like teeny, tiny river rocks. But other smokeless powders are granular like you'd expect. Chemistry is kinda neat.

>>56710510
Fuming nitric acid can be produced from electricity and air, admittedly inefficiently. It can be concentrated with distillation. Someone else had mentioned the sulfuric acid part, but this needed to catalyze the nitration and can be reused with minimal loss. A small amount could be obtained from any lab or enough car batteries for this purpose. The hardest part is the cellulose and fine extrusion needed. You would want something washed and cleaned cotton fibers, but of consistent fiber size. The forbidden spaghetti also needs to be extruded consistently with correct mixtures of petroleum (or natural grease, another consistency variable though) jelly.

>>56716111
it wasn't totally nuts. it was based off of the idea that when you start nuking the atmosphere, it turns certain layers more reflective or more absorptive to radio, which means you can't communicate long-range anymore and your over-the-horizon radars stop working. there was also the notion that you could create this effect without setting off the nukes near the enemy country - just setting them off in the atmosphere was good enough because due to spooky physics reasons this effect would propagate across the whole planet. officially, it turns out this effect does not really happen the way they thought it might (it does, it's just very weak - OR IS IT??? dun dun DUN), and of course once you start setting nuclear weapons off and the radio/radars stop working your enemy is going to be a little suspicious

Ah, the less well-known 'Tommy Colander". A practice among some German troops was to flood disabled Sherman tanks with a water-fuel mix which would then be lighted so as to boil the meat inside, then rapidly perforated with autocannon rounds so as to allow the water to drain while leaving the 'pork' (this is the origin of the term, 'steamed hams') ready for consumption. The tank crew meat would then be combined with sauerkraut and served with mashed potatoes, providing a delicious and nutritous meal to otherwise starving German soldiers. An interesting piece of history, to be sure!

>That entity was not the culmination of the wholesome beliefs of our kind, as strong as that force may be. Neither is it the avatar of the T’au’va, as some have suggested. I believe that it is instead a corruption of the Greater Good. A twisted reflection.’
‘How can that be?’
‘The other races that were with us,’ said Twiceblade. ‘They were preyed upon by the creatures in the sub-realm far earlier than us. They must have been seen as more desirable prey.’
‘Because their souls were louder, brasher. Because they could not pass by unseen.’
‘That was my conclusion, too,’ said Twiceblade. ‘They are of that realm, or connected to it, somehow. The echoes in the sub-realm… they are the reflections of those races that possess mind-science. That which exists in two dimensions at once. This is what Commander Farsight speaks of in his reminiscences, infers between the lines of those texts forbidden by the aun.’
‘The entity you witnessed. It was a human god.’

‘In a way,’ said Twiceblade. ‘That entity was the gue’vesa’s conception of our faith, given strength by the other psychic races that believe in the same tenets.’
‘We have no god!’ spat Kais, his lips curling back.
‘We do not, and rightly so,’ said Twiceblade. He was shaking, but he had come too far to go back now. ‘But to them, even a philosophy can be worshipped. To them, the line between faith in concept and faith in a divine being is thin. Perhaps even non-existent.’
‘They have created a false god,’ said Kais. His eyes were wide, his veins standing out as if he were trapped in hard vacuum. ‘The mind-science races have created a god in the image of the T’au’va.’

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56680794

Just guessing here but a combination of things. The pocket clip looks like it is probably awful, plus it has a totally unnecessary logo.
The VG-10 billboard is obnoxiously large. VG-10 is decent steel but it's more of a weeb kitchen knife steel than a pocket knife steel; you want it on a high flat grind that you can easily remove material from, not a low pseudo-scandi-whatever-the-fuck-that-is. Likewise you don't really look for that much thickness out to the tip on a sheepsfoot... this is closing in on being a prybar.
The carry profile isn't as rectangular/slim as you would normally expect from a knife like that.
Lanyard hole is in poor taste. Flipper tab looks meh.

Just a lot of little things that add up to a knife that nobody should want.

Flips do it because in the naked combat icepick grip has less reach and has more chances to glance off the ribcage. Because flips still do first blood duelling.

The grip recess fits the place where you got the thumb muscles.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56680749
Sleipner is a tool steel. I like calling it a budget version of CPM 3V. It has some corrosion resistance, decent toughness and it's very easy to sharpen. Edge retention should be somewhere between 14C28N and VG10 due to low carbide volume. Nowhere near CPM 3V and its vanadium carbides.

Sometimes people say that Sleipner is some kind of D2. Those people are retarded, it's an entirely different steel.

>>56722453
>Looked almost like KA-BAR
The history of the "hunting knife shape" is pretty interesting. single edge clip point hunting swords and hunting daggers like the hirschfanger were known since medieval times, descended from the Norman seax, and Germans, as is typical, became extremely autistic about the hunting weapons genre.
Jim Bowie popularized the American version, almost certainly modeled on/adapted from a butcher knife made by a local but England produced the vast majority of "Bowie knives" in the 1800s and beyond out of Sheffield.
Marbles in the US debuted the first proper modern hunting knife in the early 1900s and it was copied instantly everywhere- Germany's industrial base was decimated, but it still had excellent steel and cutlery factories (out of Solingen etc), but they got the hint (and didnt give a single shit about ripping off overseas designs), and started making modern hunting knives, along with sheffield, for export to the US.
WWII put a dent in that but after the war it was about as far as anyone would trust the germans with making something that could conceivably be a weapon, but the tooling and quality was still there, and they became a MASSIVE source for off-brand, store brand, and etc hunting knives in the US (as well as brand name cooking tools, Henckels etc) until Japan took over that role as the cheap overseas knife/tool maker in the 1980s. The more valuable/rarer collectibles have markings, but there's so many variations out there its a really fascinating niche. Here's another example similar to yours almost certainly from the same region

>>56722660
>no more detectable brain signals
People have come back from that lots of times. Especially when snow and ice are involved.

I assume by "Brain signals" you refer to patterns of synaptic activation?
That's not a great indicator of final death. Neurons can be inactive, not firing and then be coaxed into firing, that's not super hard to do.

If you want something definitive then it's more interesting to look at cellular death but that's hard to measure from outside the body and even that is a process, not an event.

If you read medical literature on this, you'll come across the phrase "death is a process". It's because you don't just suddenly die, instead parts of the body begin failing, eventually the brain begins failing which accelerates the rest of the body failing.
But brain death is also just a process, albeit one with a vicious feedback loop.
And actual neuron death is a process too, which can be halted and reversed under the right conditions, in laboratory settings anyway.

For the purpose of that retarded equation, a nuke sub is a nuke sub is a nuke sub. Doesn't matter if the sub opening the hatches has an american, french or chinese flag painted on, same goes for bombers. The resulting missile spam will level the target cities all t he same.

Because no russian state representative who is part of the administration would make such a statement publicly, for the reasons mentioned already.

In the game of nuclear chicken it doesn't make sense to assess countries in terms of "strong" and "weak" by looking at their conventional military potential. China may have five bazillion soldiers and israel 100k, but that doesn't matter in a nuclear exchange becazse the consequences for both sides would simply be catastrophic.

Threatening countries with a retaliatory strike doctrine (US, UK, Israel who totally doesnt have nukes wink wink etc) may lead to increased intelligence and conventional military activity against your own country or its nuclear capabilities at least. Threatening countries with a first strike doctrine (France and... maybe some others?) will lead to them striking you first in order to make sure the threat stops. Since Russia is a nuclear power that fancies itself a military super power as well, this would lead to the abovementioned missile shitspam. Just to make sure.
The reasons for that may be historical (France has been on the receiving end of the military surprise party stick twice) or they may be simply pragmatical: France is a highly centralized country, much of its economic power is concentrate around Paris, which would be a definitve strike target.
Russia knows that, France knows it as well.

TLDR; nothing is gonna happen

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56680081
NTA, I've used dacron pillow stuffing and also "cream of wheat" cereal as filler with zero issues. One application was loading .450 Nitro Express for a Thompson Encore. I've also used it when making nitro-for-black loads for .500 BPE and .300 Sherwood. The risk that I had heard was that it could theoretically leave some residue behind in the barrel which would then act as a bore obstruction. I was always super careful to inspect the barrel after every shot to see if there was any residue left behind but I never saw any evidence of that. Also keep in mind that only a tiny bit of dacron or cotton is needed to do the job. You don't cram it in there like you're ramming a muzzleloader, you just use a tiny little bit. A single cotton ball, fluffed up, would be enough to load many cartridges. I've been using the same bag of pillow stuffing for years and it still looks like it's mostly full, the amount used in any one cartridge is just a couple of grains. There simply isn't enough material to leave a bore obstruction behind. Not to mention it has massive surface area so I'm sure it all combusts during firing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56680351
I've heard people say it's dangerous. I get that.
I'm looking for proof of it actually having caused a failure. I'm totally willing to believe it's possible, I'm just asking for the proof because it's conspicuously absent from all the well known reference works on loading which actually document failures.

>>56680350
You don't. If you're using dacron or cotton you just use a tiny wisp of it, the volume it occupies is negligible. The space the filler occupies is 99.999% empty air, and quickload should treat it as such.
Sometimes I've used hard card wads aka "nitro cards" to take up space in cartridges. Those are incompressible and have non-negligible mass, so I modify the the bullet parameters to account for the extra "length" and mass of the wads.

posts.com: Could somebody with QuickLoad help a brother out? I’m reloading 7x57mm Mauser with .30-06 cases formed down to 7x57. I’m shooting a 140gr Hornady Interlock and would like to use CFE-223. Target velocity is 2,780fps

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56692870
>.30-06 cases formed down to 7x57
Check your case volume, according to GRT it should be 59.70 grains H2O. Also chec that you've got 139s, because 140 grain Interlocks are .277, not 0.284 as they should be for the 7mm.
According to GRT, with a COAL of 77.5mm and a 24 inch barrel, 45.5 grains of CFE-223 should get you right around 2780FPS, with some pressure left over in case you end up short. Note that the bullet is not fully guided in the neck, so you might want to seat it deeper which will increase the pressure but gain some velocity. See for yourself, GRT is free.

You can experiment with adding or removing a few grains, but it's unlikely to make a major difference, and even if you pack in as much powder as possible you won't come anywhere close to dangerous pressures, not even close to standard smokeless pressures.

>>56723800
Depends. You're going to have to compare to similar published loads to get an overall sanity check, and chrono some expected-mild loads to get an idea of how accurate the model is for your specific combination of components. Quickload is still generally better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56723800
Quickload and GRT are computer simulations that isn't always perfect. It's a tool you can use for helping work up loads but it's not something you should just blindly trust. Like the other anon said compare to similar published loads fora sanity check. Start mild, say 25% under max, and work from there. Remember that max power is rarely what matters most. Go with what's reliable, safe, and gives good accuracy. It's not like there is any shot on the planet where you'd have been able to make it with a 100% max load while an 80% load would fail. Use accuracy as a goalpost, not hitting max spec.

A small piece of the forcing come had broken off and the inside of the barrel had cracked. I was obviously very concerned and upset. Contacted S&W. First guy I spoke with seemed genuinely concerned for my safety when I told him what had happened. All went well but we got disconnected. Second guy sounded like I had woken him from a nap and was very rude and insincere. Told me they'd send me a postage to use for sending the gun in. I would have to pay $60 for their gunsmith to inspect my weapon and after they determined the issue they would send me an estimate for the cost of repairs. I told them to fuck themselves. Sold it as-is to a gunsmith I know and bought a Ruger. From what I hear their customer service used to be dogshit awful and since then it's improved greatly but I will still use every opportunity I get to tell that story. Haven't even considered owning anything S&W ever since.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because chemical weapons have never been nearly as effective as we'd like. The idea of it being some taboo red line that can't be crossed is partially true, but more than that, they're just not actually that useful for battlefield applications. To effectively use them (regardless of their potency) you need a pretty precise location of the enemy, a fairly accurate delivery mechanism (shells or drones), and good weather. Even then, youre releasing an area affecting weapon that immediately dissipates into the air upon release, can be countered with gas masks or suits, and if long lasting, makes pushing into that area a pain. And if you have the capabilities to deliver gas effectively, explosives do it even better.

There's a reason world war I was the only war where chemical weapons were used on the battlefield in conventional armies, and all sides figured out it wasn't a war winning weapon. Adolf didn't use it not because it would have been some moral line or unthinkable last straw, but rather be a use it wouldn't have won the war, and would have just invited the other side to use them too.

tl;dr they're more trouble than they're worth. Too finicky on the battlefield, too politically costly internationally, and even when used effectively, they don't win wars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's a lot of reasons why you don't see chemical weapons used, and they have nothing to do with morality or international agreements or the laws of warfare.

They're just not that effective under battlefield conditions at producing mass casualties, especially outdoors. You need a lot of it, even for lethal agents like nerve gases, but you can't really stockpile it because it doesn't have a long shelf life. They're also fairly easy to defend against - a gas mask and NBC suit is a fairly cheap piece of equipment. You also need a way to effectively deliver it that's not finicky (i.e. shells), but that can be equally used to deliver the same mass of high explosive, which is far more difficult to defend against because heavy armor is a lot more expensive than NBC suits.

The smartest thing the Ukrainians can do during the attrition period besides holding the line is to keep targeting Russian heavy equipment wherever they can find it. Hit it with their artillery, their guided shells, their GMLR rockets, their drones, their HARM, their JDAM, anything that can reach out and touch them. Russian tanks, artillery guns, AFV's, trucks, aircraft, supply depots, anything. Lose shit in the process if they have to, it will be replaced, the Russian shit won't. The second most important thing is training men, as many as they can. Ukraine has something like over seven million men considered fit for military service. I am not saying throw them into the war and over burden logistics, but start cycling them through basic training and get as many potential replacements ready to deploy as needed. Third I would say is equipment. The west is furnishing Ukraine for a Spring offensive, we are already seeing the armor roll in. posts.com:
I can't for the life of me find a O/U that I can aim consistently with, give me a semi-automatic for clay shooting and I'm roughly hitting on a good day for normal Trap shooting 23/25 shots, but with an O/U I'm hitting roughly 18/25 on average.
Though I'm absolutely struggling with Olympic Skeet where especially on Station 1 and 2, I can hit the high bird fine, but by the time I reorientate myself to the low bird it's usually either just high enough to hit or already on the ground by the time I have eyes on.
Any tips Anons?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56711389
The O/Us you've tried don't fit you. There's something wrong, either the length of pull or the drop of the stock. If you have a gun nearby it's fairly easy to check the drop.
Pick some point in the distance you can focus on and concentrate your vision on that point. Hold your shotgun and then quickly raise it up to your shoulder as though you are going to shoot--basically pretend that whatever spot you picked is a clay. Concentrate your vision on that spot, not the gun. Now, after you've raised the gun up, what do you see when the rib is in your vision? If you can see the rear of the rib but not the bead then your stock has too much drop and the result is that the barrels are pointing slightly down. And vice-versa: if you can see the front bead and the whole length of the rib, sort of like what a runway looks like from the perspective of a landing plane, there is not enough drop and as a result the barrels are pointing slightly high. When the drop is correct you can see the bead but not the rib because you will be looking perfectly straight down the rib. The same thing applies left-to-right: When you bring up the gun it should point straight away from you. If it wants to lean a little left or right then the "cast" is wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56723236
Shorty ARs have been a great choice for an HD 'longarm' since they've been out, don't know where you've been. They obviously have their disadvantages when it comes to power against shotguns or maneuverability against handguns, but an AR pistol will absolutely fuck shit up out to more than reasonable HD ranges, has very little recoil, has a lot of rounds on tap. and is generally easier to wield than a shotgun.
The point of .300, outside of having a substantial bullet when subsonic (.223 subs are basically centerfire .22lr), is that it doesn't loose as much out of a short barrel as 5.56 does because its less dependent on velocity and the larger diameter of the bore allows more powder to burn more quickly. Its pretty much ballistically identical to 7.62x39 (used by GIGN despite being a non-NATO cartridge for CQB rifles) and 8mm Kurtz. The heavier bullets also have an easier time getting through light barriers like glass, sheet metal, or foliage without being deflected.
Downside is that the ammo is heavier, it has marginally more recoil, is shorter range out of a rifle length barrel, and costs a whole lot more.

posts.com:
>>56723236
>why aren't .223 ar pistols a more serious home defence option?
The vast majority of people keep a dual-purpose weapon for home-defense. Usually it's a full-sized pistol or a shotgun. They aren't willing to go through the hassle of handling the dubious legal status of an AR "pistol", or filling out ATF forms, for the privilege of buying a single-tasking gun. Hell, most people I know with a home-defense gun don't even bother buying fucking defensive ammo, they just snag a couple boxes of whatever FMJ or buckshot is cheap at WalMart and move on with their lives.
A 10" carbine is definitely a viable and probably even superior option, but -- and this is extremely important -- nobody but us gunspergs really gives a fuck. They're gonna keep buying Mossbergs or cloned 870s and pumping 00 Buck through them, or popping .38spl through a 90-year-old revolver, or using their carry pistol.

As a secondary thing? You forget that a lot of us live with someone else. I can easily convince my wife that a shotgun is a worthwhile purchase and get her to practice with it. She'll even use my pistol at the range. But she won't touch most of my rifles, especially the spooky black ones. I'd rather have something I can teach her to use that maybe doesn't work quite as well (and is in fact HARDER to use well) that she'll actually shoot. As opposed to having my carbine jam up on her and get her killed.

>>56725292
400 would be a good deal without being insultingly cheap. I have a 3rd gen 23 and it's been solid, invest in a 9mm conversion barrel for it as well.
>>56723236
AR pistols exist in a bit of legal limbo with ATF and the courts hemming and hawing about the arm brace. Without a stock (just buffer tube with some foam) it's less effective but at HD ranges probably not that bad.

I think the logic is that if you want to go the AR route for an HD gun you might as well use a 16". It's longer, but you aren't going to have any questions about it being an SBR or not. Plus you run into less issues with stabilization and performance, even though that's not a big deal at short range. One major difference is reliability, because the really short 10"s tend to be picky with ammo where the 16"s with carbine or mid length gas tend to eat whatever you want.

300blk is mostly good for suppressors. It is also less negatively affected performance wise by short barrels, but it also doesn't typically have the reduced over-penetration that 5.56 has.

Sounds like you're new to this and trying things out. Pistols in general are much harder to master than most people would think. Once you get some practice 9mm out of a pistol is a piece of cake, unless you didn't like the Glock more because of the blocky grip than the recoil.
>>56721367
Because they typically don't have space to accommodate a double feed at the top of the magazine. Lots of stuff going on in that part of the pistol frame (for instance the trigger linkage usually runs past the top of the magazine well). There have been some double feed pistol magazines over the years though, Steyr GB being one.
On a rifle you can make it wider and the area around the magazine well isn't as crowded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56712100
5.7 out of a 16" barrel is pulling better velocity than 5.56 out of a 16" barrel. A 16" P90 is shorter than a 10" barrel AR. If compactness and performance out of shorter barrels is a consideration, P90 is something to look at. It's short barrel performance beats 5.56 performance out of short barrels (16" is short for velocity dependent .20 cal rounds) and the overall package is extremely space efficient. Even the mag placement is to allow max capacity in a balanced package. It's a fucking highly overlooked design that unfortunately will blow away in the wind soon like the FS2000 (which was not a good design imo, but shows FN will nuke production of something if it's not selling).

It doesn’t have to be 5.56, but there is no reason you couldn’t simply design a scaled up p90 in a cartridge approximating the performance of 5.56, with a straight walled case. 5.7 is already 50kpsi so pressure isn’t the problem. It can be done.

>>56716217
7.62x39 is not rimmed. Its rim simply follows the taper angle of the rest of the case, which is why it is a hair wider, but there is no risk of rimlock with 7.62x39, the reason rimmed rounds don’t work in mags.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56720404
Gunbroker, GunAuction.com, and occasionally Guns.com will have milsurp guns. The problem is that you’re not likely to find anything cheap. Finding them out in the world has mostly the same issue. The gun library at my Cabelas has Garands for $2k, for example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56720404
It's extremely difficult to score deals anymore thanks to the internet. Now if someone finds an old gun in Grandpa's closet or someone brings it to the pawn store they can just type whatever it says on the gun into google and know what people are paying for them. And since everybody likes to think that their gun is extra special or maybe they're just trying to maximize their return, so they ask high prices.

There's basically two ways go to about finding milsurp without getting ripped off. One is to just keep looking as much as possible--constantly scour auction listings, forums, dealers who specialize in surp, hit up the local pawn shops and LGS that carry used guns. Make sure those places know what you're looking for--you want to cultivate a relationship with them so whenever the get surp in they contact you and ask if you're interested. Eventually you will find deals, it's just a numbers game, but it's a lot harder than it was pre-internet. Use tools like saved searches on Gunbroker. Remember to search for typos and misspellings.
The other way is to buy it from a reputable auction house or a dealer who specializes in this kind of thing. The price won't be great, but it will usually be fair, and those kinds of places tend to stand behind what they sell so the risk of the gun being a fake or having problems is a lot lower.

Also do you fucking homework before you buy. Study up on the variations of the gun(s) you are interested in. Learn to identify fakes. There's a common saying among collectors for just about anything..."buy the $100 book before the $1000 gun". This is 100% true.

>>56720476
Gunsinternational is a good resource as well. Well known dealers who specialize in surp guns include Collector's Firearms and Simpson Ltd

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56723605
I do agree that real-deal auctions are usually the best, but even then you have to be careful. The prices really depend on how many of that kind of gun are in the auction. For example, say there's a big surp auction coming up at RIA, you want a G41(M) and they just happen to have one. Problem is, you have to battle it out with the other people who also want one. And depending on how many people there are and how badly at least two of them want the gun the price could go very high. On the other hand, let's say they have three of them in the auction instead. Now there are more to go around so the price won't rise as high. It doesn't necessarily even have to be the same gun; I'd expect a lone G41(M) to sell for a lot more in an auction where it was the only high-end German WWII piece, whereas if the auction also had a bunch of other similarly priced German stuff it may not have as many people fighting over it. Watch for that.

The other rule of auctions is not to get carried away in the hype. Know your budget and stick to it. Calculate in advance what your real bidding budget will be after taking into account shipping, auction fees, transfers if applicable, etc. Don't get suckered in by the hype, remember if you lose that only means you will have a bigger budget for next time. I bid on fancypants auctions a few times a year. I lose most of them. But I've gotten some damn good scores as well. Don't overpay, there will always be something cool next time in the surp/antique game.
